instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.C6990: What is C6990? Capacitor to ground on input to PP3V42_G3H power supply. PP3V42_G3H power supply turns 18.5v from charger or 8.5v-12.5v PPBUS_G3H from the battery into PP3V42_G3H. This capacitor can short to ground and keep PP3V42_G3H from turning on which would keep the machine from having a light on the magsafe charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a - no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
No liquid damage.
Getting 20V on the USB Power Meter. However, 0mAh.
No short to Ground

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0V

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
<CAPACITOR>C7075</CAPACITOR> = 5V
<CAPACITOR>C7077</CAPACITOR> = 5V
<RESISTOR>R7073</RESISTOR> = 3.3v
L7030 = 0.2V BOTH SIDE

Seems the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is bad.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a - no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Diode mode to ground at F7000?
Do you get <SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>?
What about <SIGNAL>TBA_AUX_DET</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a - no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Right now, for some reason im getting 5.15V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a - no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Diode mode to ground at F7000 AND L7030
F7000 = 0.083
L7030 = 0.364

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 2.26V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a - no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
So now you don't even get correct <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>?
Do you get 5V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?
That should be good enough for <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.

Post <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> voltages and diode mode to ground at L6990.

Compare diode mode to ground at F7000 with similar good board; 083 looks low.
Also post the value with black probe at ground.
Any big coil has the same value?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a - no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> = 5.15V
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 2.26v

<CHIP>U6990</CHIP> =
1 = 4.89V
2 = 3.29V
3 = 2.26V
4 = 0V
5 = 0V
6 = 0V
7 = 0V
8 = 3.9V
9 = 0.06V
10 = 5V

L6990 = 0.331 (diode mode to ground with red probe at ground)
F7000 = 0.075 (diode mode to ground with red probe at ground)
L7030 with black probe at ground = 0.469

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a - no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"L7030 with black probe at ground = 0.469"
I asked about F7000; is different case than old MacBook boards.

"2 = 3.29V"
No good.
Check if <RESISTOR>R6906</RESISTOR> is OK.
Post voltages for <RESISTOR>R6906</RESISTOR>, <DIODE>D6905</DIODE>, <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a - no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R9606</RESISTOR> its fine.
Voltages:
<RESISTOR>R9606</RESISTOR> = 5.2V
<DIODE>D6906</DIODE> = Pin 1 = 0 - Pin 2 = 5.2V - Pin 3 = 3.9V
<CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR> = 3.9V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a - no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Please correct your last post!

<DIODE>D6905</DIODE> (if is what you measured) shouldn't get more than 0.5V.
1.3V is too much, change it.
If still get 3.9V there, should check <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR>/91, <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
Just in case, post diode mode to ground on pin2/<DIODE>D6905</DIODE>.
Does it get hot?
